metadata.case_name: State of Orissa v. Ramnarayan Das

facts.text: The respondent was appointed in the year 1950 a Sub-Inspector on probation in the Orissa Police force.

In view of the adverse reports received against him on July 28, 1954, notice was served on the respondent calling upon him to show cause why he should not be discharged from service for gross neglect of duties and unsatisfactory work. In the notice, ten specific instances of neglect of duty and two instances of misconduct-acceptance of illegal gratification and fabrication of official record were set out.

By his explanation, the respondent submitted that action had already been taken against him by the Superintendent of Police in respect of instances of neglect of duty set out in the notice and no further action in respect thereof could on that account be taken against him, because to do so would amount to imposing double punishment. He denied the charge relating to misconduct and submitted that it was based on the uncorroborated statements of witnesses who were inimical to him. He also asked for an opportunity to cross-examine those witnesses.

The Deputy Inspector General of Police considered the explanation and observed that he had carefully gone through the representation of the probationary S.I., that his argument that he has already been punished by the S.P. for specific instances of bad work does not help him very much since all these instances of bad work during the period of probation have to be taken together in considering his merits for confirmation or otherwise, that the S.I. has already had long enough chance to work under different S.Ps., that he has not been able to procure a good chit from anyone, that he has also been adversely reported against after the representation dealt with therein was submitted, and that it is therefore not good retaining him further in service. He is discharged from the date on which this order is served on him.

The Deputy Inspector General of Police on December 11, 1954, in discharging the respondent from service, passed a formal order as follows: 'Probationary S.I. Ramnarayan Das of Cuttack District is discharged from service for unsatisfactory work and conduct with effect from the date the order is served on him.'

The respondent then presented a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Judicature, Orissa, challenging the validity of the order passed and praying for the issue of a writ in the nature of certiorari or any other writ quashing the order of discharge.

Inter alia, the respondent urged that the order of discharge was invalid since he was not given a reasonable opportunity to show cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him within the meaning of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution, and that the order of discharge was invalid since he was not afforded an opportunity to be heard nor was any evidence taken on the charges framed.

The High Court by order dated December 4, 1957, set aside the order of discharge. In the view of the High Court, the Deputy Inspector General of Police had taken into consideration allegations of corruption in passing the impugned order and also that he had refused to give to the respondent an opportunity to cross-examine witnesses on whose statements the charge of misconduct was made. The High Court observed that by discharging the respondent from service without holding an enquiry as contemplated by r.55 of the Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules and without complying with the requirements of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution, an indelible stigma affecting his future career had been cast.
Against the order issuing the writ quashing the order discharging the respondent from service, this appeal has been preferred by special leave.

The respondent was undoubtedly at the time when proceedings were started against him and when he was discharged from service, a probationer, and had no right to the post held by him. Under the terms of his appointment the respondent was liable to be discharged at any time during the period of his probation.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order of discharge of the probationer was invalid since he was not given a reasonable opportunity to show cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him within the meaning of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution.
Whether the order of discharge amounted to punishment by casting an indelible stigma affecting the respondent's future career, attracting Art. 311(2).
Whether notice to show cause under r.55-B was complied with, and whether the discharge was a simple termination of probation or dismissal by way of punishment.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notice to show cause whether the employment of the respondent should be terminated was given by r.55-B, apprising him of grounds including neglect of duty and misconduct, and his explanation was considered. The order is one terminating employment of a probationer under r.55-B, not dismissal. Mere termination does not carry evil consequences or stigma. Respondent had no right to the post and could be discharged during probation per Police Manual rules.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: r.55-B Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules; r.668, r.681 Police Manual; Art. 311(2)

petitioner_arguments.text: The enquiry was for ascertaining fitness for confirmation, not for imposing punishment on charges of misconduct. Discharge following such enquiry does not attract Art. 311(2). Distinguished cases where stigma or punishment was involved.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Parshottam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India; Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh; State of Bihar v. Gopi Kishore Prasad

respondent_arguments.text: Action already taken for neglect instances, so double punishment. Denied misconduct charges as based on uncorroborated inimical witnesses. Requested cross-examination opportunity.
Order invalid as no reasonable opportunity under Art. 311(2), no hearing or evidence taken. Discharge cast stigma without enquiry per r.55 CSA Rules.

court_reasoning.text: Notice under r.55-B was given apprising grounds, explanation considered. Order prima facie terminates probationer's employment, not dismissal. Respondent had no right to post, liable to discharge during probation per rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The Deputy Inspector General expressly observed that he had to take into account all reports in considering confirmation.

court_reasoning.text: Mere termination of probationer's service does not carry evil consequences like forfeiture of pay, loss of seniority. No indelible stigma cast by discharge for unsatisfactory work and conduct.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Use of 'discharge' not conclusive; depends on whether servant had right to post or visited with evil consequences.

court_reasoning.text: If termination founded on contract/service rules right, prima facie not punishment. But if founded on misconduct etc., then punishment attracting Art. 311. Here, enquiry to ascertain confirmation fitness, not punishment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Real test: (1) right to post? (2) evil consequences? Neither satisfied.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished Gopi Kishore Prasad: there, discharge post-enquiry into misconduct was punitive; here, for confirmation suitability.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Enquiry nature decisive: for confirmation vs. punishment.

holdings.text: Order discharging probationer following show-cause notice under r.55-B for unsatisfactory work and conduct, to ascertain confirmation fitness, is simple termination, not punishment under Art. 311(2). No right to post, no evil consequences or stigma.
High Court erred in holding discharge punitive due to stigma without enquiry; Art. 311(2) not attracted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shyam Lal v. The State of Uttar Pradesh and the Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Compulsory retirement under CSA Rules not dismissal/removal under Art. 311 even after show-cause on misdemeanors.

precedents_cited.case_name: Parshottam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Termination by contract/service rules right not punishment unless founded on misconduct or evil consequences; summarized tests for punishment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satish Chander Anand v. The Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Termination by contractual right not per se dismissal.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. Gopi Kishore Prasad
precedents_cited.relevance: Discharge post-enquiry into misconduct punitive (third proposition); but here enquiry for confirmation, not punishment.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.226 for writ petition; Art.311(2) for reasonable opportunity in punitive dismissal/removal, not simple termination.

statutes_cited.name: Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: r.55-B requires show-cause notice for terminating probationer for fault/unsuitability; complied with here.

statutes_cited.name: Police Manual of the Orissa State
statutes_cited.relevance: Probation 2 years; DIG may discharge unfitted probationer without formalities; direct appointees discharged if not competent at end.

outcome.summary: The appeal by special leave is allowed. The judgment and order of the Orissa High Court dated December 4, 1957, setting aside the discharge order is quashed. The discharge order of the Deputy Inspector General of Police dated December 11, 1954, is upheld as valid termination of probationer's service, not attracting Art. 311(2).
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; High Court writ quashed.

key_quotes.text: "If the termination of service is founded on the right flowing from contract or the service rules then, prima facie, the termination is not a punishment and carries with it no evil consequences and so Art. 311 is not attracted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core test from Parshottam Lal Dhingra for distinguishing simple termination from punishment.

key_quotes.text: "The real test for determining whether the reduction in such cases is or is not by way of punishment is to find out if the order for the reduction also visits the servant with any penal consequences."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains when termination/reduction becomes punitive under Art. 311.

key_quotes.text: "An order discharging a public servant, even if a probationer, in an enquiry on charges of misconduct, negligence, inefficiency or other disqualification, may appropriately be regarded as one by way of punishment, but an order discharging a probationer following upon an enquiry to ascertain whether he should be confirmed, is not of that nature."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes punitive enquiry from confirmation suitability enquiry.
